revision.text:
'''Remote Medical International''' ('''RMI''') operates worldwide providing medical support services for companies and individuals operating in remote environments.<ref name="Dispatch">{{cite web | url=http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/business/2009/03/02/medical_care_bizplus.ART_ART_03-02-09_C10_AQD23H7.html | title=Global link to medics a call away | publisher=''[[The Columbus Dispatch]]'' | date=March 2, 2009 | accessdate=19 July 2013 | author=Dudley, Brier}}</ref> RMI offers five main medical support services known as Core 5: RMI Staffing, RMI Topside Assistance, RMI Equipment & Supply, RMI Training, and RMI Consulting. The company serves clients in the energy sector, government and industrial services, military and law enforcement, executive protection, non-government organizations, and global logistics providers.<ref name="Dispatch"/>
==History== Remote Medical International is headquartered in Seattle, Washington, USA with employees based all over the globe.<ref name="Dispatch"/> The company was founded by Andrew Cull, a remote area paramedic in 2003. Inc. Magazine has named RMI three times as one of the 500 fastest growing companies in the US.<ref>{{cite web|author=Eric Hal Schwartz, XCONOMY |url=http://www.seattlepi.com/default/article/12-Tech-Firms-in-WA-Make-Inc-500-1305697.php |title=12 Tech Firms in WA Make Inc. 500 |publisher=seattlepi.com |date=2009-08-11 |accessdate=2013-07-20}}</ref> In 2011, Remote Medical International was listed in the "Top Twenty Places to Work" in Seattle.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seattlemet.com/issues/archives/articles/best-companies-to-work-for-in-seattle-may-2011/3/ |title=The Best Places to Work …and Play (Page 3) |publisher=Seattle Met |date=2011-04-22 |accessdate=2013-07-20}}</ref> RMI has approximately 100 employees, most of which are medical professionals.
In 2013, Remote Medical International received an $8 million investment from "Seattle-based Columbia Pacific Management, which already owns 23 hospitals in India, Malaysia, Vietnam and Indonesia through a related company, Columbia Asia."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/05/22/wa-remote-medical-idUSnBw226369a+100+BSW20130522 |title=Remote Medical International Uses $8M in Capital to Embark on Expansion |publisher=Reuters |date= |accessdate=2013-07-20}}</ref> RMI partners with [[Columbia Asia]] and uses its hospital as a base of operations in Asia.
==Overview== ===RMI Staffing=== Remote Medical International medical providers are available for onsite deployments operating in remote areas worldwide. Medical providers include experienced EMTs, paramedics, physician assistants, nurses, and doctors who respond to routine and emergent medical incidents. RMI medics are most commonly deployed on offshore seismic research vessels and land-based mineral exploration and production sites.
===RMI Topside Assistance=== In 2013, Remote Medical International launched RMI Topside Assistance, a global [[telemedicine]] service that operates out of the company's Global Coordination Center in Seattle.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/remote-medical-international-launches-rmi-connecttm-2013-07-10 |title=Remote Medical International Launches RMI CONNECT(TM) |publisher=MarketWatch |date= |accessdate=2013-07-20}}</ref> The service offers access to medical advice and logistical support 24/7 year-round via phone, internet, and video calls. The Global Coordination Center is staffed by Medical Coordination Specialists who connect clients to physicians for emergency consultation and advice and coordinate medical evacuations when necessary.
===RMI Equipment & Supply=== Remote Medical International is an authorized distributor of medical supplies and holds an export license for pharmaceuticals. RMI handles custom clearance of overseas narcotics including hazardous and [[Cold chain|cold-chain]] supply shipments worldwide. The company also operates an online store with remote medical equipment and healthcare supplies.
===RMI Training=== Remote Medical International provides remote medicine training courses taught by professionally trained and clinically active practitioners. RMI has trained over 13,000 students through public and private training courses including [[Wilderness First Aid]], [[Wilderness First Responder]], Remote Emergency Medical Technician, Remote Medicine for the Advanced Provider, and multiple recertification courses. RMI students include: all branches of the US military, energy companies, US intelligence agencies, law enforcement, FBI, executive protection, border patrol, special operations, national research organizations, National Park and Forest Services, universities, science foundations, guiding services, and individual adventurers.<ref>{{cite web|last=Fontaine |first=Scott |url=http://seattletimes.com/html/localnews/2009691742_apwacliffhangingmedics.html |title=Local News | Fort Lewis medics train for Afghanistan mountains | Seattle Times Newspaper |publisher=Seattletimes.com |date=2009-08-19 |accessdate=2013-07-20}}</ref>
===RMI Consulting=== Remote Medical International provides medical program consulting services as a solution for corporate medical needs and requirements. Examples include Medical Emergency Response Plans, Local Health Facilities Reviews, Health and Safety Audits, Onsite Health Promotion Programs and Substance Misuse Testing Services.
==See also== *[[Wilderness Emergency Medical Technician]]
==References== {{Reflist}} * [http://www.bizjournals.com/seattle/print-edition/2010/10/29/remote-medical-international-provides.html?page=all Remote Medical International provides emergency services to travelers in distant locations]. ''Puget Sound Business Journal''. * [http://seattlebusinessmag.com/article/remote-medical-international-your-global-health Remote Medical International: to your (global) health]. Seattle Business.
==External links== * {{Official|http://www.remotemedical.com}}
[[Category:Outdoor education organizations]] [[Category:Educational organizations based in the United States]]

revision.text:
{{short description|annual university ranking}} {{Use British English|date=October 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2011}} {{Infobox Magazine |title=Reuter's - The World's Most Innovative Universities |editor= |image_file=Reuters_2008_logo.svg |image_caption= |staff_writer= |frequency=Annual |circulation= |category=[[Higher education]] |publisher=''[[Reuters]]'' |firstdate=2015 |country={{uk}} |language=[[English language|English]] |website={{url|https://www.reuters.com/article/us-amers-reuters-ranking-innovative-univ/reuters-top-100-the-worlds-most-innovative-universities-2017-idUSKCN1C209R|World Ranking}}
{{url|https://www.reuters.com/article/us-emea-reuters-ranking-innovative-unive/reuters-top-100-europes-most-innovative-universities-2018-idUSKBN1HW0B4|Europe Ranking}} }} '''The World's Most Innovative Universities''' by [[Reuters]] is an annual empirical ranking that identifies educational institutions doing the most to advance science, invent technologies and power new markets.{{Cite web|url=https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2018/04/reuters-top-100-europes-most-innovative-universities-2018|title=These are Europe's most innovative universities|website=World Economic Forum|access-date=2018-10-06}}{{Cite journal|last=Vernon|first=Marlo M.|last2=Balas|first2=E. Andrew|last3=Momani|first3=Shaher|date=2018-03-07|title=Are university rankings useful to improve research? A systematic review|journal=PLOS ONE|language=en|volume=13|issue=3|pages=e0193762|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0193762|issn=1932-6203|pmc=5841788|pmid=29513762}} == Ranking == Empirical metrics focus on how often a university’s patent applications are granted, how many patents are filed with global patent offices and local authorities, and how often a university's patents were cited by others. Universities are evaluated in terms of the percentage of articles that featured a co-author from industry. The process cross references 500 academic and government organizations with the greatest number of scholarly journal articles as indexed in the Web of Science database against the patents and patent equivalents each organization filed in the same period in the Derwent World Patents Index and the Derwent Innovations Index. == Scope == The ranking has a [[Europe|European]] edition featuring the top 100 institutions across that region,{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-emea-reuters-ranking-innovative-unive/reuters-top-100-europes-most-innovative-universities-2018-idUSKBN1HW0B4|title=Europe's Most Innovative Universities – 2018|last=Ewalt|first=By David|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-10-06|language=en-US}} an [[Asia-Pacific]] edition featuring the top 75 institutions{{Cite newspaper|url=http://mobile.reuters.com/article/idUSKCN1152B7|title=Asia's Most Innovative Universities|date=30 August 2016|publisher=|newspaper=Reuters}} and an edition featuring the top 25 most innovative [[governmental]] institutions in the world.{{Cite newspaper|url=http://mobile.reuters.com/article/idUSL2N1GC1NG#listing|title=The World's Most Innovative Research Institutions – 2017|date=1 March 2017|publisher=|newspaper=Reuters}} == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:University and college rankings]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization |image= |name=Association for Computing Machinery Special Interest Group on Accessible Computing (ACM SIGACCESS) |founded_date=1971 |location= |origins= SIGCAPH |key_people= |area_served=International |focus=[[Accessible computing]] |revenue= |endowment= |owner= |Non-profit_slogan= |former name= |homepage={{URL|http://www.sigaccess.org/}} }} '''ACM SIGACCESS''' is the [[Association for Computing Machinery]]'s [[Special Interest Group]] on [[Accessible computing]], an interdisciplinary group of academic and industrial researchers, clinicians and rehabilitation personnel, policy makers, end users, and students to develop technologies for use by people with disabilities.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hanson|first1=Vicki L|title=ACM's Commitment to Accessibility|journal=Communications of the ACM|volume=60|issue=3|page=7|doi=10.1145/3047268|url=https://cacm.acm.org/magazines/2017/3/213833-acms-commitment-to-accessibility/fulltext|accessdate=5 May 2017}}</ref>
==History== In 1964, the [[Association for Computing Machinery]] started a Committee on Professional Activities for the Blind, which published a newsletter for four years and organized a conference in 1969. The purpose of the committee was to promote and support [[blind people]] as capable programmers.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Sterling|first1=Theodor D.|last2=Lichstein|first2=M.|last3=Scarpino|first3=F.|last4=Stuebing|first4=D.|title=Professional Computer Work for the Blind|journal=Communications of the ACM|date=1 April 1964|volume=7|issue=4|pages=228–230|doi=10.1145/364005.364054|url=http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=364054|accessdate=5 May 2017|issn=0001-0782}}</ref> The committee broadened its focus to include other people with disabilities and became the "Special Interest Group on Computers and the Physically Handicapped" (SIGCAPH) in 1971.<ref name="p_thesis">{{cite web|last1=Petrick|first1=Elizabeth|title=Fulfilling the promise of the personal computer : the development of accessible computer technologies, 1970-1998|url=http://escholarship.org/uc/item/6242116r|website=UC San Diego Electronic Theses and Dissertations|publisher=UC San Diego|accessdate=5 May 2017|language=en|date=1 January 2012}}</ref> In 2003, the SIG was renamed to SIGACCESS.<ref name="p_thesis"/>
==Conferences== The ACM SIGACCESS Conference on Computers and Accessibility ([[ASSETS]]) is the flagship annual conference. All conference contributions are [[peer-reviewed]] by an international program committee, and accepted papers, posters and demonstrations are archived in the [[ACM Digital Library]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The International ACM SIGACCESS Conference on Computers and Accessibility|url=http://assets17.sigaccess.org/|website=ACM ASSETS 2017|accessdate=5 May 2017|language=en}}</ref> All authors of accepted papers will be invited to submit extended versions of their papers to a special issue of the ''ACM Transactions on Accessible Computing'' (''TACCESS'').
SIGACCESS also sponsors other ACM workshops and conferences on a rotating basis.<ref>{{cite web|title=Related Conferences|url=http://www.sigaccess.org/assets/related-conferences/|website=SIGACCESS|accessdate=5 May 2017}}</ref>
==Journal== ''[[Transactions on Accessible Computing]]'' is a quarterly ACM journal that publishes refereed articles about [[accessible computing]]. The journal places emphasis on contributions with experimental results, but also accepts papers with new theoretical insights or positions.<ref>{{cite web|title=TACCESS|url=http://www.rit.edu/gccis/taccess/index.html|website=ACM Transactions on Accessible Computing|publisher=ACM|accessdate=5 May 2017}}</ref>
SIGACCESS also publishes the ''Accessibility and Computing'' newsletter.<ref>{{cite web|title=Newsletter|url=http://www.sigaccess.org/category/news/newsletter/|website=SIGACCESS|accessdate=5 May 2017}}</ref> ==Awards== ===ASSETS Paper Impact Award=== The ASSETS Paper Impact Award is given to authors whose papers have made a significant impact on the field. Papers must be at least ten years old to be considered.<ref>{{cite web|title=Impact Award|url=http://www.sigaccess.org/category/news/awards/impact-award/|website=SIGACCESS|publisher=ACM|accessdate=6 May 2017}}</ref>
===Outstanding Contribution to Computing and Accessibility Award=== The Outstanding Contribution award is given in even-numbered years and recipients give a keynote presentation at the following ASSETS conference.<ref>{{cite web|title=SIGACCESS|url=https://awards.acm.org/sig-awards/sigaccess#h-sigaccess-award-for-outstanding-contributions-to-computing-and-accessibility|website=ACM Awards|accessdate=6 May 2017|language=en}}</ref>
Previous recipients: * 2016 - [[Richard E. Ladner]] * 2014 - [[Vicki L. Hanson]] * 2012 - [[John A. Gardner]] * 2010 - [[Albert M. Cook]] * 2008 - [[Jim Thatcher]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Association for Computing Machinery}}
[[Category:Association for Computing Machinery Special Interest Groups]] [[Category:Computer accessibility]] [[Category:Assistive technology]]

revision.comment: link [[credit score]] using [[:en:User:Edward/Find link|Find link]]
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=March 2017}}
'''Student loan refinancing''' is an aid needed by students who have some problems paying their [[Student loan]] on time. A student may consider refinancing student loans when he/she cannot handles payments with multiple loans. Multiple loans can be described as multiple interest rates. By refinancing student loans, students may be able to consolidate their multiple loan payments into one low interest rate. Students may significantly lower their recurring premiums by refinancing their loans.
==Process== Student loan lenders will buy out your loan from your existing servicer, allowing you to have a new loan at a potentially lower interest rate. This process will also consolidate all of the loans you refinance into one convenient payment.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Loan Consolidation {{!}} Federal Student Aid|url = https://studentaid.ed.gov/sa/repay-loans/consolidation|website = studentaid.ed.gov|accessdate = 2015-11-10}}</ref> Like any form of debt, your goal with a student loan should be to pay as low an interest rate as possible. Other than a mortgage, you will likely never have a debt as large as your student loan. If you are able to reduce the interest rate by refinancing, then you should consider the transaction.
You need to find a lender willing to refinance your student loans and borrowers generally want that offer to result in savings over their existing loans. Then, you submit your personal information to them (which often includes loan balance, income, [[credit score]]) to get a personalized refinancing offer. If you get an offer that you like, you then usually need to send them a few documents (e.g. a pay stub) to prove the information you provided is true and then sign on the new loan. There are existing loan comparison tools such as student-lending marketplaces to help borrowers get the transparency of rates they deserve.
Loan approval rules vary by lender. However, all of the lenders will want:
Show that you can afford your payments.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Student Loan Refinancing Marketplace|url = https://www.credible.com/blog/best-companies-to-refinance-and-consolidate-your-student-loans/|website = credible.com|accessdate = 2017-03-07}}</ref> For instance, proof of a job with an income that is sufficient to cover your student loan et al. Show that you are a responsible borrower, with a demonstrated record of on-time payments. For some lenders, that means that they use the traditional FICO, requiring a good score. For other lenders, they may just have some basic rules, like no missed payments, or a certain number of on-time payments required to prove that you are responsible.
==See also== * [[Student debt]] * [[Student loan]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Education finance]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2013}} {{Infobox writer | name = Susan Johanson
[[Order of Canada|CM]] [[Registered Nurse|RN]] | image = | caption = Sue Johanson | birth_name = Susan Powell | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1930|3|16|}} | birth_place = [[Toronto]], Ontario, Canada |alma_mater=[[University of Michigan]] | occupation = Public speaker, sex educator, writer | genre = Sex education and health | movement = | website = {{URL|http://www.talksexwithsue.com}} | nationality = [[Canadians|Canadian]] }} '''Sue Johanson''', {{Post-nominals|CM}} (born March 16, 1930) is a Canadian writer, public speaker, [[registered nurse]], [[sex education|sex educator]], and media personality. ==Biography== ===Early life=== Johanson was born '''Susan Powell''' in [[Toronto]], Ontario, to Wilfrid Powell, a decorated British war hero,{{Citation needed|date=August 2007}} and an affluent Ontario-born [[Irish people|Irish]] [[Protestant]] mother, Ethel Bell. Her great-uncle was [[Robert Baden-Powell, 1st Baron Baden-Powell|Lord Baden-Powell]]{{Citation needed|date=May 2011}}. Her mother died when Johanson was ten. Johanson attended nursing school in St. Boniface Hospital [[Winnipeg]], graduating as a registered nurse. Soon after, she married a [[Swedish Canadian|Swedish-Canadian]] electrician named Ejnor Johanson. They had three children: Carol, Eric and Jane. The family moved to [[North York]], where Johanson kept house and raised her children. In 1972, Johanson opened a [[birth control]] clinic in [[Don Mills Collegiate Institute|Don Mills CI]] high school, the first of its kind in Canada. She worked there as clinic coordinator until 1986. She continued her education at the Toronto Institute of Human Relations (a postgraduate course in counseling and communication), the [[University of Toronto]] (family planning), and the [[University of Michigan]] (human sexuality), graduating as a counselor and [[sex education|sex educator]]. ===Career=== Johanson's career rose rapidly since her first classroom teaching in the North York schools. Later some other districts of the country noticed her performances and began to invite her in schools and universities all over the country. Johanson's humour and frankness make her a popular speaker at Canadian universities. She frequently packs auditoriums to capacity, making even standing room hard to come by. ===Radio and TV programs=== Johanson achieved popularity as a sex educator and [[psychotherapy|therapist]] on [[rock music|rock]] radio station [[CILQ-FM|Q107]]. Originally she had a one-hour phone-in radio show dedicated to advice on sex. Later, the show was increased to two hours. The show was called ''[[Sunday Night Sex Show]]'' and existed for nineteen years between 1984 and 2005. In 1985 this radio program was turned into a TV talk show with the same name on the [[community television]], [[Rogers Cable]]. In 1996 it became a national show on the [[Women's Television Network]] (WTN) with a high rating. The first seven seasons were delivered to American audiences by [[Oxygen (TV network)|Oxygen Media]] in 2002. The recorded program was very popular, but American viewers missed the opportunity to call in and ask their own questions. The U.S. version of ''Sunday Night Sex Show'', called ''Talk Sex with Sue Johanson'', produced especially for American audiences, debuted in November 2002 on the Oxygen Media. ''Talk Sex with Sue Johanson'' was an educational talk show airing every Sunday night. The program was divided into a several segments all covering the following topics: sexual life, love and relationships. Call-in segment includes viewers' live calls with questions immediately being answered by Sue. The discussions included the most common worries about arousal or [[erection]], pregnancy, [[contraception]], infections, and diseases. Johanson easily covered such topics as [[BDSM]], [[sex position]]s, sexuality trends, sex and age, and much more. The show also included a sex quiz, a sex poll where viewers could vote via the internet and see the results at the end of the episode, and included important sexual news and information before and after commercial breaks. The "Hot Stuff Bag" segment of the show was dedicated to reviewing a new [[sex toy]] which has been tested out by one or more members of the crew. The toy is shown and its usage is explained, as well its pros and cons. It is then rated on a scale of 1–4. The show also usually includes a book review. The educational format of the show combined with Johanson's profound knowledge of the subject and healthy sense of humour made the program popular with all age groups. Approximately 4.2 million Americans watch the show every Sunday. The show appears in Israel, Brazil, and twenty [[list of European countries|European countries]] in five languages. Johanson made two cameo appearances in the teen drama ''[[Degrassi Junior High]]'' as "Dr. Sally", essentially a fictionalised version of herself. She reprised the role a decade later for two episodes of ''[[Degrassi: The Next Generation]]''. It was announced on May 7, 2008, that Sunday night's episode on May 11, 2008, would be her last, opting to retire. Johanson ended the show very emotionally and was joined by her staff on stage as she said goodbye. ===Books=== Johanson is the author of three books: ''Talk Sex'' ({{ISBN|0-14-010377-5}}), ''Sex Is Perfectly Natural but Not Naturally Perfect'' ({{ISBN|0-670-83856-X}}), and ''Sex, Sex, and More Sex'' ({{ISBN|0-06-056666-3}}). All of them cover the sex topics from different points and include the detailed answers of the most delicate questions asked commonly about sexual life, Johanson's advice and health information. Johanson is also the author of a weekly column published in the Health section of the ''[[Toronto Star]]'' newspaper. ===Awards and honours=== Johanson's work educating and informing the public about birth control and sexual health earned her Canada's fourth highest honor (after the [[Victoria Cross]], [[Cross of Valour (Canada)|Cross of Valour]], and the [[Order of Merit]]), appointment to the [[Order of Canada]] in 2001, for lifetime achievement.http://archive.gg.ca/honours/search-recherche/honours-desc.asp?lang=e&TypeID=orc&id=6771, 2011-05-28 In 2010, Johanson was presented the Bonham Centre Award from the Mark S. Bonham Centre for Sexual Diversity Studies for her contributions to the advancement and education of issues around sexual identification.http://media.utoronto.ca/media-releases/arts/sexual-diversity-centre-at-u-of-t-to-give-citizenship-award-to-renowned-oxygen-network-sex-educator-sue-johanson/, 2010-09-09 ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://talksexwithsue.com/ Talk Sex with Sue Johanson] *{{IMDb name|id=1200710|name=Sue Johanson}} *[http://www.tv.com/sue-johanson/person/187391/biography.html Sue Johanson bio at tv.com] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Johanson, Sue}} [[Category:1930 births]] [[Category:Canadian nurses]] [[Category:Canadian talk radio hosts]] [[Category:Canadian television hosts]] [[Category:Canadian people of British descent]] [[Category:Canadian people of Irish descent]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of the Order of Canada]] [[Category:Writers from Toronto]] [[Category:Relationships and sexuality writers]] [[Category:Sex educators]] [[Category:University of Toronto alumni]] [[Category:University of Michigan alumni]] [[Category:Female broadcasters]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2014}} {{Use British English|date=January 2014}} [[File:SwarthmoreLecture2006-May-27.jpg|thumb|right|200px|2006 Swarthmore Lecture at Friends House, London.]] '''Swarthmore Lecture''' is one of a series of lectures, started in 1908, addressed to [[Britain Yearly Meeting]] of the [[Religious Society of Friends]] (Quakers). The preface to the very first lecture explains the purpose of the series.
“This book is the first of a series of public addresses to be known as the Swarthmore Lectures. The Lectureship was established by the Woodbrooke Extension Committee, at a meeting held December 9th, 1907. The Minute of the Committee provides for “an annual lecture on some subject relating to the Message and Work of the [[Religious Society of Friends|Society of Friends]].” The name “[[Swarthmoor Hall|Swarthmore]]” was chosen in memory of the home of [[Margaret Fell|Margaret Fox]], which was always open to the earnest seeker after Truth, and from which loving words of sympathy and substantial material help were sent to fellow-workers. “The Woodbrooke Extension Committee requested [[Rufus Jones (writer)|Rufus M. Jones]], M.A., D.Litt., of [[Haverford College]], [[Pennsylvania]], to give the first lecture on the evening preceding the holding of the Friends’ [[Britain Yearly Meeting|Yearly Meeting]] of 1908. In accordance with this decision, the lecture was delivered in the [[Methodist Central Hall, Birmingham|Central Hall]], [[Birmingham]], on May 19th. “The Swarthmore Lectureship has been founded with a two-fold purpose: firstly, to interpret further to the members of the Society of Friends their Message and Mission; and secondly, to bring before the public the spirit, the aims and the fundamental principles of the Friends. This first lecture presents Quakerism as a religion of experience and first-hand reality—a dynamic, practical religion of life.”
The transcripts of the 2000, 2002, 2003, 2004, 2006, 2008 and 2011 lectures (not necessarily the text printed in the books listed below) are available as free downloads from the [http://www.woodbrooke.org.uk/publications.php?action=search&category=4 Woodbrooke Quaker Study Centre website]. Reviews of some lectures are online on the Nayler blog.[http://www.nayler.org/?cat=52 Nayler blog reviews of some Swarthmore lectures.] == List of Swarthmore Lectures == {| class="wikitable" cellpadding="5" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;" width="100%" !width="7%"|Year !width="25%"|Author !width="38%"|Title !width="30%"|Notes |- |align="center"|1908 |align="center"|[[Rufus Jones (writer)|Rufus M. Jones]] |''Quakerism: a Religion of life''[https://archive.org/details/quakerism00joneuoft The text of Rufus Jones' 1908 Swarthmore Lecture is available online at the Internet Archive] | |- |align="center"|1909 |align="center"|[[William Charles Braithwaite]] |''Spiritual Guidance in the experience of the Society of Friends''[https://archive.org/details/cu31924084550098 The text of W. C. Braithwaite's 1909 Swarthmore Lecture is available online at the Internet Archive] | |- |align="center"|1910 |align="center"|[[Joan Mary Fry]] |''The Communion of Life'' | |- |align="center"|1911 |align="center"|[[Thomas Hodgkin (historian)|Thomas Hodgkin]] |''Human Progress and the Inward Light'' [https://archive.org/details/humanprogressand00hodguoft The full text of Thomas Hodgkin's 1911 Swarthmore Lecture is available online at the Internet Archive] | |- |align="center"|1912 |align="center"|Terrot Reaveley Glover |''The Nature and Purpose of a Christian Society [https://archive.org/details/naturepurposeof00glov The full text of T. R. Glover's 1912 Swarthmore Lecture is available on line at the Internet Archive]'' |For biographical information on the lecturer, see the [[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]] article.{{cite ODNB|id=33427|title=Glover, Terrot Reaveley (1869–1943)|first=Herbert H.|last=Huxley|accessdate=28 Jan 2007}} |- |align="center"|1913 |align="center"|[[Joshua Rowntree]] |''[[Social Service - its place in the Society of Friends]]'' | |- |align="center"|1914 |align="center"|[[Edward Grubb (Quaker)|Edward Grubb]] |''The Historic and Inward Christ: a study in Quaker thought'' |For biographical information on the lecturer, see the [[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]] article.{{cite ODNB|id=71530|title=Grubb, Edward (1854–1939)|first=Thomas C.|last=Kennedy|accessdate=28 Jan 2007}} |- |align="center"|1915 |align="center"|[[Silvanus P. Thompson]] |''The Quest For Truth'' [https://archive.org/details/questfortruth00thomrich Online text of the 1915 Lecture by Sylvanus P Thompson on the Internet Archive] | |- |align="center"|1916 |align="center"|Henry T. Hodgkin |''The Missionary Spirit and the Present Opportunity'' | |- |align="center"|1917 |align="center"|William Littleboy |''The Day of Our Visitation'' | |- |align="center"|1918 |align="center"|Lucy Fryer Morland |''The New Social Outlook'' | |- |align="center"|1919 |align="center"|Lucy Violet Holdsworth (also known as Hodgkin) The lecture was published under the author's maiden name: L.V. Hodgkin |''Silent Worship : The way of wonder''[https://archive.org/details/silentworshipway00hodgiala The text of L.V.Holdsworth's 1919 Swarthmore Lecture is available online at the Internet Archive] | |- |align="center"|May 1920 | align="center" |Herbert G. Bailey |''Peace is a Process'' |{{ISBN|0-85245-249-7}} |- |align="center"|1994 |align="center"|Margaret Heathfield |''Being together : our corporate life in the Religious Society of Friends'' |{{ISBN|0-85245-254-3}} |- |align="center"|1995 |align="center"|Anne Thomas |''Only Fellow-Voyagers. Creation stories as guides for the journey'' |{{ISBN|0-85245-272-1}} |- |align="center"|1996 |align="center"|Jonathan Dale |''Beyond the Spirit of the Age'' |{{ISBN|0-85245-282-9}} |- |align="center"|1997 |align="center"|Christine Trevett |''Previous Convictions and end of the millennium Quakerism'' |{{ISBN|0-85245-290-X}} |- |align="center"|1998 |align="center"|[[Young Friends General Meeting]] |''Who do we think we are? Young Friends' Commitment and Belonging'' |{{ISBN|0-85245-299-3}} |- |align="center"|1999 |align="center"|Alex Wildwood |''A faith to call our own. Quaker tradition in the light of contemporary movements of the Spirit'' |{{ISBN|0-85245-312-4}} |- |align="center"|2000 |align="center"|Tim Newell |''Forgiving Justice. A Quaker vision for criminal justice'' |Original: {{ISBN|0-85245-321-3}}
2007 reprint: {{ISBN|978-0-901689-51-1}} |- |align="center"|2001 |align="center"|Tony Stoller |''Wrestling with the Angel'' |{{ISBN|0-85245-326-4}} |- |align="center"|2002 |align="center"|Jackie Leach Scully[http://nndr.org/2012/02/10/death-by-a-thousand-cuts/ Portrait of J L Scully, with comments on UK Government policy on disability benefits (2012)] |''Playing in the Presence: genetics, ethics and spirituality'' |{{ISBN|0-85245-337-X}} |- |align="center"|2003 |align="center"|Eleanor Nesbitt |''Interfaith Pilgrims: living truths and truthful living'' |{{ISBN|0-85245-347-7}} |- |align="center"|2004 |align="center"|Simon Fisher |''Spirited living : waging conflict, building peace'' |{{ISBN|0-85245-357-4}} |- |align="center"|2005 |align="center"|Helen Steven |''No Extraordinary Power: Prayer, Stillness and Activism'' |{{ISBN|0-85245-379-5}} |- |align="center"|2006 |align="center"|Roger and Susan Sawtell |''Reflections from a Long Marriage'' |{{ISBN|0-85245-394-9}} |- |align="center"|2007 |align="center"|Beth Allen |''Ground and Spring: the foundation of Quaker Discipleship'' |{{ISBN|978-0-901689-67-2}}, [http://www.quaker.org.uk/shared_asp_files/GFSR.asp?NodeID=93671 BYM Press Release] |- |align="center"|2008 |align="center"|Christine A. M. DavisChristine A M Davis, the 2008 lecturer, currently has an entry in ''Who's who'' (July 2011). [http://www.scotsman.com/news/obituaries/obituary-christine-davis-cbe-public-servant-1-3705568 Her obituary in ''The Scotsman" 2 March 2015 by Rowena Loverance, with portrait photograph] |''Minding the Future'' |{{ISBN|0-901689-88-2}}
{{ISBN|978-0-901689-88-7}} |- |align="center"|2009 |align="center"|Peter Eccles |''The presence in the midst: reflections on discernment'' |{{ISBN|978-1-907123-03-0}}, the 2009 Swarthmore Lecture was given during [http://www.ymg.org.uk/ Yearly Meeting Gathering] at University of York on Tuesday 28 July.2009 Swarthmore lecture: Preview by John Fitzgerald in ''The Friend'' 6 March 2009, page 9 |- |align="center"|2010 |align="center"|Paul Lacey |''The unequal world we inhabit'' |{{ISBN|978-1-907123-12-2}}, the 2010 Swarthmore Lecture was given during Yearly Meeting in London on Saturday 29 May 2010.{{cite web|url=https://bookshop.quaker-secure.org.uk/shop/unequal-world-we-inhabit-swarthmore-lecture-2010|title=Quaker Centre Bookshop - The unequal world we inhabit - Swarthmore Lecture 2010|accessdate=16 June 2010}} |- |align="center"|2011 |align="center"|Pam LunnPam Lunn, the 2011 lecturer is a tutor at Woodbrooke Quaker Study Centre, Birmingham, who blogs at [http://woodbrookegoodlives.blogspot.com/ woodbrookegoodlives.blogspot.com].[http://www.nayler.org/?p=350 Review of 2011 Lecture by Jez Smith] |''Costing not less than everything: Sustainability and spirituality in challenging times'' |The 2011 Swarthmore Lecture was given at Yearly Meeting Gathering in Canterbury on Monday 1 August 2011. {{ISBN|978-1-907123-21-4}} |- |align="center"|2012 |align="center"|Rachel Brett |''Snakes and Ladders: A personal exploration of Quaker work on human rights at the United Nations'' |The 2012 Swarthmore Lecture was given at Yearly Meeting in London, on 26 May 2012. It was published by Quaker Books. A free MP3 audio is available from the [http://www.woodbrooke.org.uk/news.php/310/woodbrooke-at-britain-yearly-meeting-and-2012-swarthmore-lecture Woodbrooke website.] |- |align="center"|2013 |align="center"|Gerald Hewitson |''Journey Into Life: Inheriting the story of early Friends'' |The 2013 Swarthmore Lecture was given at Yearly Meeting in London, on 25 May 2013. {{ISBN|978-1-907123-47-4}}. Available online as an Audio recording .MP3, Text (Word document) and Text (PDF) at the [http://www.woodbrooke.org.uk/publications.php?action=publication&id=99 Woodbrooke website] |- |align="center"|2014 |align="center"|Ben Pink Dandelion[http://www.woodbrooke.org.uk/pages/swarthmore-2014.html Woodbrooke announcement of 2014 lecturer and topic.] |''Open for Transformation: being Quaker'' |The 2014 Swarthmore Lecture was given during [http://www.quaker.org.uk/ym Yearly Meeting Gathering] at the University of Bath on Sunday 3 August 2014. {{ISBN|9781907123689}}. An online audio recording is available.[https://soundcloud.com/swarthmorelecture Swarthmore Lecture 2014 audio recording.] |- |align="center"|2015 |align="center"|[[Diana Francis (Peace activist)|Diana Francis]] |''Faith, power and peace'' |The 2015 Swarthmore Lecture was given during Britain Yearly Meeting at Friends House, London on Saturday 2 May 2015 |- |align="center"|2016 |align="center"|Esther Mombo and Cecile Nyiramana |''Mending broken hearts; rebuilding shattered lives - Quaker peace building in eastern Africa'' |The 2016 Swarthmore Lecture was given during Britain Yearly Meeting at Friends House, London, May 2016 |- |align="center"|2017 |align="center"|Catherine West MP and Cllr Andy Hull |''Faith in politics?'' |The Swarthmore Lecture 2017: Faith in politics? A testimony to equality was given by Catherine West at 7:30 pm on Monday 31 July 2017 as part of Yearly Meeting Gathering at Warwick University. ISBN 9 781999 726904 |- |align="center"|2018 |align="center"|Chris Alton |''Changing ourselves, changing the world'' |The 2018 Swarthmore Lecture was given during Britain Yearly meeting at Friends House, London on the 5th of May.https://www.woodbrooke.org.uk/swarthmore-lecture-2018-changing-ourselves-changing-the-world |- |align="center"|2019 |align="center"|Eden Grace |''On Earth, as it is in Heaven'' |The 2019 Swarthmore Lecture will be given during Britain Yearly meeting at Friends House, London in May, dv.''The Friend'' 2018-11-16 pp.10-11. Interview - Eden Grace interviewed by Oliver Robertson |} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Quakerism in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Lecture series]] [[Category:1908 establishments in the United Kingdom]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=August 2017}}
'''Tuteria''' is a Nigerian platform for offline and online [[tutor]]ing, co-founded in 2015 by Godwin Benson and Abiola Oyeniyi, [[Systems engineering|systems engineers]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/tobyshapshak/2016/05/07/exclusive-real-solutions-to-real-problems-named-in-innovation-prize-for-africa-2016-finalists/2/#48423f7572c0|title=Exclusive: Real Solutions To Real Problems Named In Innovation Prize For Africa 2016 Finalists|last=Shapshak|first=Toby|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-07-12}}</ref>
== Background == Goodwin Benson and Abiola Oyeniyi launched Tuteria -a tutoring platform- in June 9, 2015 after Godwin Benson left [[Deloitte]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://valourdigest.com/godwin-benson/|title=Godwin Benson: Every Situation Has a Solution {{!}} Valour Digest|work=Valour Digest|access-date=2017-07-12|language=en-GB}}</ref> The platform is intended to link tutors with Nigerian learners. Benson was inspired by his own experience as a tutor to launch this project and Abiola Oyeniyi who is one of the top Python developers in Nigeria is the CTO of Tuteria and writes the code.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-40030337|title=Nigerian tutoring app Tuteria wins UK engineering award|date=2017-05-24|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-07-12|language=en-GB}}</ref>
The selection of potential tutors is ensured by a verification process that includes an ID and qualifications check along with standard competency tests.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://techmoran.com/tuteria-launched-to-ease-neighborhood-tutoring-in-nigeria/|title=Tuteria launched to ease neighborhood tutoring in Nigeria - TechMoran|website=techmoran.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-12}}</ref>
== Awards == In April 2015, Tuteria’s developers were among the winners of the Microsoft Mobile devices and services “Passion to Empire” campaign. The start-up was able to raise N3.5million during this campaign.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://under35ceo.co/2015/07/21/interview-with-godwin-benson-founder-of-tuteria/|title=INTERVIEW WITH GODWIN BENSON, FOUNDER OF TUTERIA|website=Under35CEO|access-date=2017-07-12}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cp-africa.com/2015/06/23/cp-africa-interviews-godwin-benson-founder-of-tuteria-com/|title=CPAfrica Interviews Godwin Benson, Founder of Tuteria.com|date=2015-06-23|website=CPAfrica|access-date=2017-07-12}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bellanaija.com/2017/02/bellanaijamcm-turning-passion-to-profit-tuterias-godwin-benson-is-contributing-to-educational-development-in-nigeria/|title=#BellaNaijaMCM: Turning Passion to Profit! Tuteria's Godwin Benson is Contributing to Educational Development in Nigeria - BellaNaija|website=www.bellanaija.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-12}}</ref>
In 2016, Tuteria won the Internet.org innovation challenge for education.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://lifestyle.thecable.ng/nigerian-startup-wins-facebook-sponsored-innovation-challenge/|title=Nigerian startup wins Facebook-sponsored innovation challenge|website=The Cable|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref>
In May 23, 2017, Tuteria won Africa Prize for Engineering Innovation<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.raeng.org.uk/news/news-releases/2017/may/nigerian-innovation-wins-the-africa-prize-for-engi|title=raeng.|last=|first=|date=2017|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and received a US$32,000 prize by UK’s [[Royal Academy of Engineering]].<ref name=":0" />
== Services == The website caters for a wide range of learners and it has 450 approved subjects with 6 main fields: mathematics, science, business, music, languages and computer science.<ref><nowiki>http://techcabal.com/2015/06/08/nigeria-based-neighbourhood-peer-education-platform-tuteria-launches-tomorrow/</nowiki></ref>
The tutoring platform also accommodates for other handcrafts and skills like bead-making, [[dance]] and [[photography]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://innovation-village.com/qa-godwin-benson-co-founder-tuteria/|title=innovation-village|last=|first=|date=|website=innovation-village.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-07-12}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://ngcareers.com/job/2015-06/private-tutor-and-instructor-at-tuteria/|title=Private Tutor and Instructor at Tuteria June, 2015|last=Ngcareers|work=Ngcareers|access-date=2017-07-12}}</ref>
== Funding and revenue == Tuteria received a $20 000 grant from Niara-Africa Inspire and Microsoft Lumia Nigeria.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://techcabal.com/2015/09/22/godwin-benson-talks-about-his-hyperlocal-marketplace-for-tutors/|title=Godwin Benson talks about his hyperlocal marketplace for Tutors {{!}} TechCabal|access-date=2017-07-12}}</ref>
The tutoring platform generates revenue from commissions on lessons booked via the website or the mobile application. Tuteria charges 15 to 30% for each paid lesson.<ref name=":1" />
== References == {{reflist}} * * * *
[[Category:Nigeria]] [[Category:Appropriate technology]] [[Category:Nigerian inventions]] [[Category:Online education]] [[Category:Distance education]] [[Category:2015 establishments in Nigeria]]

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[Emirati]] (link changed to [[Emiratis]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
'''Wedad Nasser Lootah''' ({{lang-ar|'''وداد ناصر لوتاه'''}}, sometimes [[transliterated]] as '''Widad Naser Lutah''', born in 1964) is an [[Emiratis|Emirati]] [[marriage counselor]] working for [[Dubai]]'s main [[courthouse]], and the author of the Arabic sex guide ''Top Secret: Sexual Guidance for Married Couples'', published in 2009.<ref name=nytimes>{{cite news | title = Challenging Sex Taboos, With Help From the Koran | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/06/world/middleeast/06dubai.html?ref=global-home | date = June 5, 2009 | accessdate = June 10, 2009 | first = Robert F. | last = Worth | publisher = ''[[The New York Times]]'' }}</ref> She caused a controversy in the Islamic world by discussing sensitive topics in her book, such as [[Oral sex in Islamic law|oral sex]], the [[Islamic view of anal sex|danger of anal sex]], female orgasm, the necessity of [[sex education]], and [[Homosexuality and Islam|homosexuality in Islamic societies]].<ref name=nytimes/> Although Lootah's frankness earned praise from liberal Muslims, it also drew death threats from fundamentalists who consider the book blasphemorous and her "an [[infidel]], and a sinner".<ref name=nytimes/><ref name=arabnews>{{cite news | title = Book on sex education creates stir in UAE | url = http://www.arabnews.com/?page=24&section=0&article=119643&d=26&m=2&y=2009 | first = Shadiah | last = Abdullah | publisher = ''[[ArabNews]]'' | date = February 26, 2009 | accessdate = June 10, 2009 }}</ref> However, Lootah claims that none of her advice in the book violates the teachings of the [[Qur'an]] and that the book was published after the [[Mufti]] of Dubai gave an approval, even though he warned her that "Arab readers might not be ready for such a book".<ref name=nytimes/>
Lootah wrote in her book that many men have their first sexual experiences with other men in [[Saudi Arabia]] and other Muslim countries with strict [[gender segregation]], which she claims negatively affects their sex life in marriage later.<ref name=nytimes/> In her interview with ''[[The New York Times]]'', Lootah commented that "many men who had anal sex with men before marriage want the same thing with their wives, because they don't know anything else. This is one reason we need sex education in our schools."<ref name=nytimes/>
Lootah has been working as a marriage counselor at the Family Guidance section in the Dubai Courthouse since its opening in 2001, and remains the only female counselor there.<ref name=nytimes/> Her ''Top Secret'' is the first sexual guidebook published in the [[United Arab Emirates]].<ref name=arabnews/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.islameyat.com/post_details.php?id=1551&cat=28&scat=27& Wedad Lootah's interview] with [[Qatar]]'s [[Middle East Media Research Institute]] (MEMRI) in 2005
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lootah, Wedad}} [[Category:1964 births]] [[Category:Emirati Muslims]] [[Category:Emirati writers]] [[Category:Emirati sexologists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Muslim writers]] [[Category:People from Dubai]] [[Category:Sex educators]] [[Category:Sexuality in Islam]]

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{notability|Organizations|date=August 2012}} {{primary sources|date=August 2012}} {{more citations needed|date=August 2012}} }}
{{Infobox organization | logo = WCE Logo.jpg | type = [[501(c)3]] | founded_date = 2000 | founder = | location = [[Hull, Massachusetts]] | origins = | key_people = | area_served = | product = | focus = Computer reuse and education | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = 300–400 active | num_employees = 2 | num_members = | subsid = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = | homepage = [http://www.worldcomputerexchange.org/ worldcomputerexchange.org] | dissolved = | footnotes = }}
'''World Computer Exchange''' (WCE) is a United States Canada based charity organization whose mission is "to reduce the [[digital divide]] for youth in developing countries, to use our global network of partnerships to enhance communities in these countries, and to promote the reuse of electronic equipment and its ultimate disposal in an environmentally responsible manner." According to [[UNESCO]], it is North America's largest non-profit supplier of tested used computers to schools and community organizations in developing countries.<ref> {{cite web|title=Computer Donation|url=http://www.unesco.org/education/aladin/resource.html#Computer%20Donation|work=Support for Resource Centres and Libraries|publisher=UNESCO Institutaion for Education|accessdate=5 April 2013}}</ref>
== History ==
The organization was founded in 1999 by Timothy Anderson. <ref>http://bcm.bc.edu/issues/winter_2011/works/net-worker.html</ref> <ref>http://earth911.com/news/2010/12/06/earth911-holiday-charity-spotlight-world-computer-exchange/</ref> <ref>http://www.hks.harvard.edu/news-events/publications/hks-magazine/archives/winter-2012/classnotes#1998</ref>
The organization is a [[non-profit organization]], and tax-exempt under section 501(c)(3) in the US.<ref>http://www.bbb.org/charity-reviews/national/education-and-literacy/world-computer-exchange-in-hull-ma-7108/tax-status</ref> WCE headquarters is in Hull, Massachusetts, and there are 15 chapters in the USA and five in Canada.<ref>http://www.worldcomputerexchange.org/chapters</ref><ref>http://williamsreport.wordpress.com/2012/12/18/around-town-2/</ref><ref>http://www.fcdigitalworkshop.com/2013/fcdw-partners-with-world-computer-exchange/</ref><ref>http://studentinvolvement.orgsync.com/show_profile/55954-world-computer-exchange-wsu</ref><ref>http://www.facebook.com/WCEPalouse</ref> In 2015, WCE opened a chapter in Puerto Rico.<ref>https://prcorpfiling.f1hst.com/CorpInfo/CorporationInfo.aspx?c=353066-122</ref>
By November 2002, the organisation shipped 4,000 computers to 585 schools in many developing countries. <ref>http://www.sfgate.com/business/article/New-life-for-old-PCs-Nonprofit-group-collects-2770167.php</ref>
By October, 2011, along with partner organizations, WCE has shipped 30,000 computers, established 2,675 computer labs. <ref>http://www.thebcobserver.com/2011/10/18/winston-center-welcomes-world-computer-exchange-president-founder/</ref> <ref>http://www.worldcomputerexchange.org/about-us</ref> In February 2012, Boston chapter (also headquarters chapter) in Hull, Massachusetts sent out their 68th shipment bringing their total to 13,503 computers.<ref>http://www.worldcomputerexchange.org/boston-ma</ref>
== Activities==
WCE provides computers and technology, and the support to make them useful in the developing communities. WCE delivers educational content and curriculum on agriculture, health entrepreneurship, and even water and energy. The program also ensures that teachers will know how to use the technology and content by providing staff and teacher training, as well as ongoing tech team support.<ref>{{cite web|title=EdTech for the Third World: Tech Tools|url=http://takefiveblog.org/2013/04/18/edtech-for-the-third-world-tech-tools/|work= EdTech for the Third World: Tech Tools|publisher=George Washington University Institute for Public Policy and Global Communication|accessdate=29 April 2013|date=18 April 2013}}</ref>
Each chapter of WCE collects donated computers, refurbishes and prepares the shipment for the projects. While preparing shipments, they also raise funds to ship the computers.<ref>http://bostoncares.force.com/HOC__Organization_Profile_Page?Oid=001A000000bA6nJIAS</ref> <ref>http://www.worldcomputerexchange.org/volunteer</ref><ref>http://www.mnn.com/lifestyle/recycling/stories/electronics-recycling</ref><ref>http://artsdigitalera.com/organizations-donating-used-laptops-to-developing-nations/</ref><ref>http://www.fcdigitalworkshop.com/2013/fcdw-partners-with-world-computer-exchange/</ref> Volunteers of WCE chapters inspect each computer, repair if necessary, install operating system as well as educational material to each computer.<ref>http://blogs.vmware.com/careers/2011/11/vmware-foundation-employees-give-back-the-world-computer-exchange.html</ref><ref>http://www.worldcomputerexchange.org/chicago-il</ref>
WCE calls recipients of its computers "partners." The requests of computer donations originate from the partners. Once the refurbished computers and the funds to ship the computers are fulfilled, WCE initiates shipment. When possible, WCE coordinates the shipments of computers with other non-profit organizations, such as [[University of the People]], [[Peace Corps]],<ref>http://playbook.peacecorpsict4d.org/toolkits/grants-and-funding/</ref> Computers4Africa.org,<ref>http://www.computers4africa.org/impact/beneficiaries.htm</ref> ADEA (Assoc. for the development of Education in Africa) and others. <ref>http://whereintheworldisclaire.blogspot.com/2009/04/you-obviously-know-value-of-computer.html</ref> <ref>http://agentdstorm-senegal.blogspot.com/2011/08/expanding-worlds-of-students-with-books.html</ref> <ref>[[University of the People#World Computer Exchange]]</ref> <ref>http://www.uopeople.org/groups/partners/wce</ref> <ref>http://www.iearn.org/news/article/iearn-and-world-computer-exchange-team-ecorps-program</ref> <ref>http://envaya.org/ccdo/history</ref> <ref>http://www.atencionsanmiguel.org/2015/03/11/world-computer-exchange-provides-computers-training-to-mexican-children/</ref>
In November 2015, WCE sent two 2 Spanish speakers to visit Honduras for 2 weeks in 2015 to pilot an employable tech skills training for youth under a WCE contract with [[World Vision]].<ref>http://www.worldcomputerexchange.org/ecorps</ref>
The WCE Computers for Girls (C4G) initiative is field testing of eight tools to provide technological training and [[Science, technology, engineering, and mathematics|STEM]] education for interested teachers helping their girl students in four West African countries (Ghana, Liberia, Mali, and Zambia)<ref>http://www.worldcomputerexchange.org/Computers-for-Girls</ref> and Pakistan.<ref>http://www.worldcomputerexchange.org/computers-girls-pakistan</ref>
In September 2016, World Computer Exchange-Puerto Rico and 4GCommunity.org, two not-for-profit corporations, have announced their alliance to improve public school and family access to technology where needed throughout Puerto Rico. <ref>http://www.caribbeannewsnow.com/topstory-Non-profit-alliance-works-to-improve-access-to-technology-in-Puerto-Rico-31695.html</ref>
== eCorps== To install the computers at a partner site without access to experts otherwise, WCE recruits and supports [[volunteering|volunteers]] from the USA under its "eCorp" initiative. To be eligible, volunteers must be 21 years of age, have necessary tech skills, and be prepared to self-fund their travel and accommodation expenses. 18 eCorps training teams have worked in Dominican Republic (2), Ethiopia, Georgia, Ghana (2), Honduras, Kenya, Liberia, Mali, Nepal, Nicaragua, Nigeria, Philippines, Puerto Rico, Tanzania (4), and Zimbabwe.<ref>http://www.worldcomputerexchange.org/ecorps</ref><ref>http://www.volunteerforever.com/volunteer_profile/bryan-barton</ref><ref>http://worldcomputerexchange.org/ecorps-nicaragua-2012</ref>
The eCorps "Travelers" program is geared towards those already planning to go to one of the countries in the WCE network, to provide tech support during their trip. 79 eCorps "Travelers" have visited the following 41 developing countries including: Armenia, Bolivia (2), Cambodia, Cameroon, Democratic Republic of Congo, Dominican Republic (2), Ecuador, Ethiopia, Haiti, Honduras, India (2), Indonesia, Jordan, Kenya (2), Liberia, Malawi, Mexico (2), Namibia, Nepal, Pakistan, Palestine, Panama, Peru (2), Puerto Rico, Qatar, Senegal, Sierra Leone, South Africa (2), Swaziland, Tanzania (2), Togo, and Uganda. In FY'15, "Travelers" visited: Cambodia, Haiti, Honduras, Mexico, Puerto Rico, and South Africa.<ref>http://www.worldcomputerexchange.org/ecorps</ref>
== Computers == WCE uses [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]] operating system to prepare computers, citing the cost of license and less prone computer viruses while providing sufficient computing environment such as [[word processor]] and [[printer driver]]s.<ref>http://www.worldcomputerexchange.org/why-ubuntu</ref> Unlike [[One Laptop per Child]], the prepared computers do not contain specialized software. Each computer is loaded with educational materials which allows users to learn materials without internet connection.
==See also== *[[Computer recycling]] *[[Electronic waste in the United States]] *[[Empower Up]] *[[FreeGeek]] * [[Geekcorps]] * [[Geeks Without Bounds]] * [[Global digital divide]] * [[ICVolunteers]] * [[Information and communication technologies for development|Information and communication technologies for development (ICT4D)]] * [[Inveneo]] * [[NetCorps]] * [[NetDay]] *[[Nonprofit Technology Resources]] * [[Kofi Annan#United Nations Information Technology Service .28UNITeS.29|United Nations Information Technology Service (UNITeS)]]
==External links== * http://www.worldcomputerexchange.org
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Computer recycling]] [[Category:Information technology organizations|Charities]] [[Category:Information technology education|Charities]] [[Category:Charities based in Massachusetts]]
